comments.body: Is this the right thing to do? How do we help people not make configuration errors?

I initially opted to do nothing but was not sure if this was the correct thing to do, so I added the test to explicitly draw out this behavior. As it appears to me, we have three options:

1. do nothing
2. log an error
3. throw an error (possibly a 404 or 500)

Thinking about it some more, we should at least log something, if not opt for an error. Do you have a particular preference? I don't think this will be a common user interaction with kubernetes, since it involves modification of the manifest file for the kube-apiserver, which I imagine will only mostly only be necessary on the cloud-provider level.

I'm tempted to say to throw an error, and the only reason I didn't suggest it is the case where we remove a health check that could currently be in the config files.

We could add in the code a list of removed health checks + a test exercising all existing ones to ensure it stays up to date?

I'm actually okay with throwing an error. Removing a health check wholesale is pretty backwards incompatible, so I would think that a change like that would be almost impossible to get in without breaking lots of things. If we wanted a change like that, I think it'd be better to version the healthz endpoint (v2), or have other people exclude the removed health check in their cloud provider manifests themselves.
Maybe we just `glog.Warningf` from apiserver if we see an unknown check being excluded - same path as a deprecated flag?

Sorry, was adding the error behavior when i caught this bug [#70752](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/70752). I've fixed it in a separate PR [70753](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/70753). I'll wait to merge that one before proceeding here.

> I'm tempted to say to throw an error, and the only reason I didn't suggest it is the case where we remove a health check that could currently be in the config files.

Throwing an error makes it harder to skew across versions and support rollback without modifying config/deployment logic.

That's a good point, I hadn't considered the rollback scenario. Is it typical to rollback versions without also changing the manifest file? It would be possible to exclude a check that exists in a version, which does not exist in the previous one, but this is problematic when maintaining the same manifest file across versions, I think.
@deads2k, is it common to rollback versions without also changing the manifest file?
Opted for @justinsb's suggestion to log the warning.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +86,90 @@	}{
		{"?verbose", "[+]ping ok
healthz check passed
", http.StatusOK, false},
		{"?exclude=dontexist", "ok", http.StatusOK, false},
		{"?exclude=bad", "ok", http.StatusOK, true},
		{"?verbose=true&exclude=bad", "[+]ping ok
[+]bad excluded: ok
healthz check passed
", http.StatusOK, true},

comments.body: This set of patterns doesn't seem to match our "normal" mechanism of `/stepA` for overall and `/stepA/details` for details of it.

	req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", "http://example.com/healthz/test", nil)
	if err != nil {
